p: Nettle : The “Nettle” plant is found abundantly throughout Ireland ( Jackson, 2014). It is generally identified as Urtica dioica although there is also a small nettle variety, Urtica urens that is very similar. In the SMC, it was mostly recommended as a “spring tonic,” or good for “blood.” There is a long history of use of Nettle in Ireland as a tonic ( Allen and Hatfield, 2004; Dolan, 2007; Ballard, 2009; Jackson, 2014) Dioscorides describes how when nettle leaves are cooked together with mussels they soothes the stomach, drive away flatulence and propel the urine ( Leonti et al., 2009). Additionally, The European Medicines Agency has listed the use of U. dioica L., U. urens L., their hybrids or their mixtures, radix, based on well-established use as a herbal medicinal product for the relief of lower urinary tract symptoms related to benign prostatic hyperplasia ( European Medicines Agency, 2012).
